conflictDescription: User Story A requires ALFRED to block all non-emergency notifications during work hours, forbidding notifications. User Story B requires the caregiver to control notifications for each client, allowing notifications. These opposite instructions on notification handling for the same event cause a Start-Forbid conflict.
userStoryASummary: As a medical caregiver, I want ALFRED to block all non-emergency notifications during my work hours, so I can focus fully on patient care without distractions.
userStoryBSummary: As an informal caregiver, I want to control notifications for each client myself, so I can avoid overload and stay ready to help.

conflictDescription: User Story A requires blocking all non-emergency notifications during work hours without exceptions, while User Story B requires manual selection of notifications per client, allowing some non-emergency notifications. These impose different frequencies and scopes of notification delivery that cannot be satisfied at the same time under the same conditions.
userStoryASummary: As a medical caregiver, I want ALFRED to block all non-emergency notifications during my work hours, so I can focus fully on patient care without distractions.
userStoryBSummary: As an informal caregiver, I want to choose which notifications I get from ALFRED for each client, so I can focus and not get too many alerts.

conflictDescription: User Story A requires ALFRED to automatically and strictly log all clinical actions without extra effort, while User Story B requires video calls to be planned only when clients agree. These create conflicting conditions for when ALFRED should perform logging or initiate communication, as one is automatic and strict, the other conditional on client consent.
userStoryASummary: As a medical caregiver, I want ALFRED to automatically and strictly log all my clinical actions to keep precise records without extra effort.
userStoryBSummary: As an informal caregiver, I want to plan video calls only when clients agree, so I can support their activity participation without forcing them.

conflictDescription: User Story A requires strict automatic logging of all clinical actions by medical caregivers, while User Story B involves informal caregivers scheduling video calls for games at flexible times. These stories have different triggering events and operations related to communication and record-keeping, making their conditions for operation inconsistent.
userStoryASummary: As a medical caregiver, I want ALFRED to automatically and strictly log all my clinical actions to keep precise records without extra effort.
userStoryBSummary: As an informal caregiver, I want to invite clients to video calls for games at their time, so they feel comfortable and engaged without pressure.

conflictDescription: User Story A expects direct and clear communication without delays, while User Story B requires planning video calls only with client agreement, which can forbid communication without consent. These oppose each other on when and how communication happens.
userStoryASummary: As a medical caregiver, I want to communicate with patients in a direct and clear way to save time and avoid distractions during my busy shifts.
userStoryBSummary: As an informal caregiver, I want to plan video calls only when clients agree, so I can support their activity participation without forcing them.

conflictDescription: User Story A expects direct and clear communication to save time, while User Story B expects video calls at the patient's time to avoid pressure, which can slow or soften communication. These are opposite instructions for communication style under similar events.
userStoryASummary: As a medical caregiver, I want to communicate with patients in a direct and clear way to save time and avoid distractions during my busy shifts.
userStoryBSummary: As an informal caregiver, I want to invite clients to video calls for games at their time, so they feel comfortable and engaged without pressure.

conflictDescription: User Story A wants to force hard exercises without allowing difficulty changes, which is a strict and firm action. User Story B wants to send gentle medication reminders to avoid stress, aiming for a softer approach. The opposing ways of applying forceful versus gentle actions under the same cluster 'Reminder Control' create contradictory expectations on system behavior.
userStoryASummary: As a medical caregiver, I want to force patients to do hard exercises without letting them change difficulty, so I can meet clinical goals.
userStoryBSummary: As an informal caregiver, I want to send gentle medication reminders to my clients so I can help their health without making them feel stressed.
